bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jan H. Tillisch, February 16, 1948

div1.p: Hench discusses his yellow fever research. He informs Tillisch that he is searching for an aerial photograph of the area around Camp Lazear, but has been unable to locate one.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jan H. Tillisch, February 16, 1948
div1.p:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
February 16, 1948 Dr. Jan H. Tillisch
Mayo Clinic
My dear Jan:

I believe you know that I am writing a book on the “Conquest of
Yellow Fever” featuring the work of Dr. Carlos Finlay of Havana and that of
Major Walter Reed and his colleagues of the U. S. Army Board who did their
epoch-making work in Cuba in 1900. I have spent about 9 years collecting
material during which time I have visited Cuba three times.

So far I have been unable to find one item I am very anxious to
have--an aerial photograph of a strip of land in Quemados de Marianas, suburb
of Havana. I have searched many places for this, so far in vain. I have con-
sulted the photographic files of the National Geographic Society in Washington.
They have 2 or 3 fine aerial photos of Havana extending from Morro Castle on
the east to the Hotel Nacional on the west (see enclosed photo). Recently I
visited the Photographic Department of the U. S. Navy; they produced two good
aerial views of the city proper but nothing as far “west” as Quemados.

The last time I was in Cuba the authorities at the Military Hospital,
Ciudad Militar (Old Camp Columbia) gave me two or three five photos but they only
showed the Hospital Militar and little else.

Not knowing where else to turn I asked the advice of U. S. Naval
Photographers who suggested that the Pan American Airways Photographic or
Publicity Offices in Havana might already have just the photos I want. Now
this is where you come in. Having been in the humble ground forces in the late
war I didn't get to know many Air Corps men, nor do I know anyone connected with
Pan American here or in Havana. But I thought that you, while “up in the wild
blue yonder”, might have fraternized with someone connected with Pan American
and through you I might get a helpful introduction.

Mary and I are leaving this week for Florida and Cuba. I speak in
Washington next Wednesday, February 18; then on the 19th we go to Palm Beach
to stay at the Villa Atlantique, Palm Beach from February 19th to March 1st
when we will go to Cuba for a week staying at the Hotel Nacional.

Jan, do you know anyone connected with Pan American in Miami, or
better yet, in Havana? I certainly would like to call at their offices and see
if per chance they do have what I have hunted for so long in vain.

I enclose two maps which show the strip I'd like to have a photograph
of.

MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
Dr. Jan H. Tillisch
-2-
February 16, 1948

I'd love to have a photo showing the strip which stretches from the
La Playa beach to the Oriental Park, Quemados and which would also show some-
thing of the Military Hospital (I don't care about the rest of the camp; its of
little interest to me), the La Playa railroad spur and in particular the Finca
San Jose with its adjacent quarry. The Finca San Jose is an old estate (with
remains of a farm in the rear) on Calzada Real which is well marked by an orna-
mental sign on the iron-grilled gate. Everyone in Quemados knows it.
Now why do I want photos of this particular strip? For these reasons:

On the exact spot where the present military Hospital now stands there
stood in 1900 the Camp Columbia Post Hospital, U. S. Army, where Walter Reed,
Lazear and their colleagues began their work (#1 on my pencilled drawing).
Walter Reed erected a secret experimental camp in the rear of the Finca San Jose
and erected there their famous two little experimental buildings (“Buildings 1 and
2”). In 1940 I rediscovered Building 1 which is still there! As a result the
Cuban government recently made this little building (only a shack 14x20 feet) a
“National Monument.” The remains of this little building I have marked as #2 on
my pencilled map.

When the volunteers developed experimental yellow fever they were at
once removed to a group of little wooden yellow fever “wards” right a cross the
La Playa railroad track from the present Military Hospital on which site there is
now a tree and (until recently) a memorial sign and fence. This spot is at #3 (my
drawing).

The headquarters of General Lee were the Nerve-Center of Military
activities in Quemados in 1900; these headquarters were in a fine old building
which still stands on Calzada Real at the spot I've marked #4 (my drawing).

I'd love to have an air view which shows all these 4 spots and because
American tourists know the La Playa Beach (#5 on drawing) so well it would be fine
indeed to have that in the background (or foreground) to serve for purposes of
orientation. In May in Washington will be held the International Congress on
Tropical Medicine; on May 18 before a distinguished audience will be given a
special ceremony in honor of Walter Reed. The Surgeon General and other govern-
mental and diplomatic persons will be on the platform. I have been asked to give
“the principal oration” on that occasion and expect to illustrate my address with
slides. Two days later, May 20, a bust of Walter Reed is to be unveiled in the
Hall of Fame, New York University; I have just been asked to assist somehow with
the program of that event. Hence my desire to get the air views mentioned.

On previous visits I have travelled from Miami to Havana by Pan American.
On one occasion I tried to photo what I wanted myself but I only have a small
hand camera, unsuitable for good air views; also the Pan American planes never
fly far enough west. They approach from the north, circle over the Hotel Nacional,
then the Principe Hill or the Colm Cemetery and then circle east to land on the
(rear) harbor. Even if I could persuade a pilot to go the 2 or 3 miles fatther
west I fear I could never get an adequate photo myself with my small camera. Once
I got some movies or tried to but as one lands it gets bumpy and one goes so fast
(and only once) over the place that my efforts were futile.

MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
Dr. Jan H. Tillisch
February 16, 1948

I would be delighted to pay a reasonable fee for such photos but I
am hoping they are already taken by someone. A chartered plane, etc. would
I fear cost me more than I can allow for just 2 or 3 slides or photos. So I'm
hoping Pan American may already have such photos or refer me to some Havana
photo agency that might have them.

As far the desirable height for the photos I wouldn't dare to guess.
The enclosed National Geographic Photo is a little high for detail but is
pretty good at that!

Whatever you can do or suggest, Jan, I will surely appreciate. I
enclose a reprint which will remind you of the story I'm so interested in.
Sincerely,
P. S. Hench, M. D.
PSH:ktb
February 16, 1948
Jan:

Perhaps you might send (airmail) to Doctor McDonald the original
copy of this letter, also one carbon in case he wants to forward it to Miami.
Also, please send him my photos, maps and drawing. I would like to have them
back sometime from Doctor McDonald or his associates in Havana (but, if not,
its o.k.).

If Pan American doesn't have the photos, I do hope they can refer
me to someone in Havana who might have them. Does Cuba have an air force
which takes photos?
Thanks very much!
PSH:ktb
